CH.coreZoneText: Danger level "considerable" (3+) in all aspects above 3400m.

avalancheProblems.comment:
80 to 120 cm of snow will fall until Monday above approximately 3500 m. The fresh snow and the wind slabs formed by the moderate to strong southerly wind are prone to triggering. Persons can release avalanches easily, including large ones. Natural avalanches are to be expected.
The current avalanche situation calls for caution and restraint.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Snowpack

In September, snow repeatedly fell at higher elevations. In the glaciated high mountains, above around 3400 m, there is a continuous snowpack.

On Monday, large amounts of snow will fall, especially at the highest elevations. Avalanches may release over large areas.

Below around 3400 m, the snow usually falls on bare ground.

tendency.comment:
Outlook

Tuesday:

It is mostly very cloudy, with occasional bright spells in the inner Alpine regions. At higher altitudes, a strong southerly wind blows at times. Along the main Alpine ridge, from the Monte Rosa region to Avers and further south, 30 to 60 cm of snow will fall in the high mountains. The avalanche danger increases locally there. In other regions, only little precipitation falls, with the snowfall level lowering to 2200 m in the west and 2800 m in the east. There the avalanche danger does not change significantly.

Wednesday:

It remains mostly very cloudy, with occasional bright intervals in the south. Precipitation occurs in showers. The snowfall level is between 1800 m in the west and 2200 m in the east and south. In the high mountains, the avalanche danger decreases slowly, but at higher elevations small slides are to be expected with the fresh snow.

CH.coreZoneText: Danger level "considerable" (3=) in all aspects above 3400m.

avalancheProblems.comment:
Over a wide area 40 to 80 cm of snow will fall until Monday above approximately 3500 m. The fresh snow and the wind slabs formed by the moderate to strong southerly wind are prone to triggering. Persons can release avalanches easily, including medium-sized ones. Natural avalanches are possible.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Snowpack

In September, snow repeatedly fell at higher elevations. In the glaciated high mountains, above around 3400 m, there is a continuous snowpack.

On Monday, large amounts of snow will fall, especially at the highest elevations. Avalanches may release over large areas.

Below around 3400 m, the snow usually falls on bare ground.

Tuesday:

It is mostly very cloudy, with occasional bright spells in the inner Alpine regions. At higher altitudes, a strong southerly wind blows at times. In other regions, only little precipitation falls, with the snowfall level lowering to 2200 m in the west and 2800 m in the east. There the avalanche danger does not change significantly.

It remains mostly very cloudy, with occasional bright intervals in the south. Precipitation occurs in showers. The snowfall level is between 1800 m in the west and 2200 m in the east and south. In the high mountains, the avalanche danger decreases slowly, but at higher elevations small slides are to be expected with the fresh snow.

CH.coreZoneText: Danger level "moderate" (2=) in all aspects above 3200m.

avalancheProblems.comment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow will fall until Monday above approximately 3000 m. The fresh snow and the wind slabs formed by the moderate to strong southerly wind are prone to triggering. Persons can release avalanches. In some cases these are medium-sized. The avalanches are otherwise rather small.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
